subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Call of Cthulhu fixes
msgSnippet: ... Sure.  The whole point of the namer dot, like the capital letter in TO, is to prevent the reader from trying to work out whether something is an obscure
messageBody:
Nathan Sharfi scripsit:

> Incidentally, does "Legrasse's" need a namer dot?

Sure. The whole point of the namer dot, like the capital letter in TO,
is to prevent the reader from trying to work out whether something is
an obscure (or even a common) noun or just a name that shouldn't be
interpreted for meaning. In German, where all Nouns are capitalized
at all Times, you can have sentences like "The Tiger jumped out and
ate the unfortunate Fir-tree" ("Der Tiger sprang heraus und aß den
unglücklichen Tannenbaum"), where only common Sense tells you that
Tigers don't eat Trees, and therefore "Tannenbaum" must be someone's Name.

--
John Cowan http://ccil.org/~cowan cowan@...
[P]olice in many lands are now complaining that local arrestees are insisting
on having their Miranda rights read to them, just like perps in American TV
cop shows. When it's explained to them that they are in a different country,
where those rights do not exist, they become outraged. --Neal Stephenson
